conclusion: To determine the time at which objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs of both objects.
The distance traveled by each object can be found by integrating the velocity with respect to time.
Object A has a velocity that increases linearly with time.
Object B has a velocity that decreases initially and then increases, forming a parabola.
The position \( s_A(t) \) of object A can be found by integrating its velocity \( v_A(t) \).
The position \( s_B(t) \) of object B can be found by integrating its velocity \( v_B(t) \).
For object A, if the velocity is \( v_A(t) = mt \), then the position is \( s_A(t) = \frac{1}{2}mt^2 \).
For object B, if the velocity is \( v_B(t) = at^2 \), then the position is \( s_B(t) = \frac{1}{3}at^3 \).
The distance between the two objects at time \( t \) is \( d(t) = |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| \).
To find the time at which the distance is maximized, we need to find the time at which the derivative of the distance with respect to time is zero.

The distance \( d(t) = |s_A(t) - s_B(t)| \) can be complex to differentiate directly, so we can instead find the time at which the velocities are equal, as this is when the distance is either increasing or decreasing at the rate of zero.
From the graph, we can see that the velocities are equal at \( t = t_1 \).
This is the time at which the two objects are closest together before they start to move apart again.

The distance is farthest when the velocities are equal and the objects are moving in opposite directions or when the velocities are not equal and the object with the higher velocity is far ahead of the other.
From the graph, we can see that the distance is farthest at \( t = t_2 \).
This is the time at which the velocities are equal and the objects are moving in the same direction but the object A is far ahead of object B.
The time at which the two objects are farthest apart is \( \boxed{t_2} \).
